summary.seg: This is one of the earliest copies of an important Commentary on Leviticus by Ralph of Flavigny (Flaix), a Benedictine monk written circa 1150. This was the standard commentary on Leviticus until at least the mid-13th century. The text gives instructions on ritual, legal and moral practices which are God's covenant with the Jews.

This Trinity Hall manuscript dates from the second half of the 12th century and was made for Simon, Abbot of St Albans (1167-1183). The illumination of this manuscript is very distinctive and can be linked stylistically to other work by the artist known as the “Simon Master”, identifiable through the style of the figures and facial types in his historiated initials and his use of green outline for the initial frames. On folio three, there is a notable first initial of the letter V, within which is portrayed in strong colours, the seated figure of Moses being addressed by God.
The manuscript was given to Trinity Hall by Hare, Robert Robert Hare (d. 1611).

decoNote.p: There are at the beginning of the book some admirable decorative initials in gold and colours. These have a green edging. They should be compared with two MSS. at Trinity College, B.5.3 and O.5.8. The initials in question are on f.2r, f.3v (this is a pink initial with gold filling, and inside ground of gold, on blue ground. Within it is Moses, with red nimbus, white beard, pink mantle over white, kneeling. On R. in green medallion a bust of Christ with red nimbus holding a scroll which has been inscribed in cent. xv. (Hutton Ricardo Ihesu miserere memento), f 13 e (Lib. II), f. 21 b (Lib. III), f. 3o b (Prol. and text of Lib. iv). After this the initials have no grounds, and no gold is employed.

provenance.p: From St Alban’s. At the top of f.1v is:
Hunc librum fecit dominus symon abbas sancto albano quem qui ei abstulerit aut titulum hunc deleuerit anathema sit.
On the recto in a good imitation of a xvth cent. hand, very large and black,
Liber Roberti Hare precium .x. solid’. anno christi m.d. lxx.
and the title Radulphus flaviensis super leviticum.

recordHist.source: Description draws on James, M. R. (1907). A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Trinity Hall.

listBibl.bibl: James, M. R. (1907). A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Trinity Hall. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp. 4-5.
Smalley, Beryl. “Ralph of Flaix on Leviticus.” Recherches De Théologie Ancienne Et Médiévale, vol. 35, 1968, pp. 35–82. www.jstor.org/stable/26188093
